awd_titl_txt: Excellence in Research: Collaborative Research on Nanosensors to Develop Research Capacities at Interdisciplinary Materials Research and Education Laboratory (IMREL)
awd_abstract_narration:
This Excellence in Research (EIR) project, proposed by three investigators at Fayetteville State University (FSU), is to conduct interdisciplinary collaborative research on nanosensors including physical, chemical and biochemical sensors. A sensor is used to detect the changes in its environment, such as temperature, waves, electric/magnetic/electromagnetic fields, chemicals, etc., and a sensor made at the nanoscale may achieve higher sensitivities, extended detection limits, enhanced mechanical, physical and chemical properties, and high-throughput detection. This research includes three subprojects: (1) nanoscintillators for fast X-ray detection; (2) conjugated polymers and small molecules for optical sensing; and (3) highly sensitive electrochemical and fluorescent biochemical sensors based on oxide nanofibers for beta amyloid protein detection. The proposed research will be integrated with the education of undergraduates at FSU. FSU is a Historically Black University focusing on the education of African American students, with high female, military or military-affiliated student populations. This project carries with three project goals to: (1) build a strong collaborative research team for research in physical, chemical and biochemical sensors; (2) enhance infrastructure to support nanomaterials research; and (3) train the next generation of materials scientists and STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics) professionals in nanosensors research. The integration of research and education will improve the STEM educational quality of Materials Science minors from multiple STEM departments based on evidence-based practices, significantly enhancing the educational quality of undergraduates through the research-oriented education. 

Crosslinked with electronic structures and optical luminescence properties of nanomaterials, this EIR project will be conducted collaboratively: (1) research on physical sensors of nanoscintillators for fast X-ray detection will investigate factors controlling fast X-ray detection, and potentially identify new fast scintillator materials with optimized tunable emissions through chemical doping; (2) manipulation of optical properties of conjugated polymers and small molecules will provide important insights into how these systems can be applied as chemical sensors, and will provide directions for future design of  cost-effective and highly sensitive solid-state chemical nanosensors using these materials; and (3) using oxide nanofiber scaffolds with high porosity and large surface areas, research on immunosensor will allow highly sensitive, selective, rapid  and repeatable detection of beta amyloid. challenges of current enzyme sensors. The fast X-ray detection is highly desirable in a wide range of scientific time-resolved experiments to detect rapid pulsed radiations, such as the transient deformation or transformation process under extreme conditions in materials research. Optical sensing using conjugated polymer and small molecules will provide a simplified strategy for solid-state chemical sensing and is highly desirable to detect singlet oxygen, charge/ionic species and radicals. Immunosensors based on oxide nanofibers hold several promises for applications in biological, food, environmental and energy sciences. These advanced nanosensors will impact the hazard detection, disease detection, environmental monitoring, and exo-terrestrial monitoring.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

por.por_cntn:
This Excellence in Research (EIR) project was funded to enhance the research capacities in materials research at the NSF-supported Interdisciplinary Materials Research and Education Laboratory (IMREL) at Fayetteville State University (FSU). Focused on three primary goals, the project aimed to build a strong collaborative research team for advancing physical, chemical, and biological sensor research, enhance infrastructure to support cutting-edge nanomaterials research, and train the next generation of materials scientists and STEM professionals in nanosensor technology. These objectives elevated FSU’s research capabilities and strengthened its role in STEM education, particularly for underrepresented groups.

The project was organized to promote synergistic interdisciplinary research in physical, chemical, and biological sensors, emphasizing their electronic and optical luminescence properties. Through collaborative efforts, it expanded the fundamental knowledge and methodologies for studying nanosensors in diverse scientific contexts. External partnerships with North Carolina State University and Argonne National Laboratory provided access to state-of-the-art research facilities and expertise in nanoscale technologies. These collaborations enriched the research environment at FSU, facilitated knowledge exchange, and positioned the university for advanced materials research. Internally, the project fostered faculty collaboration and enhanced research infrastructure, enabling the university to establish new capabilities in materials science. This progress was reflected in producing 19 research publications and delivering 10 research presentations, making contributions to the scientific community. Moreover, the project benefited faculty and external collaborators for interdisciplinary collaboration in materials research and education.

The project provided research training opportunities to approximately six students annually. Over the project period, 16 undergraduate students were recruited, representing a range of STEM disciplines such as biology, chemistry, forensic science, materials science, and physics. Notably, the cohort reflected FSU’s commitment to diversity, with 50% identifying as minorities, 69% as females, and 13% as veterans. These students were fully engaged in the research process, including sample synthesis, characterization, advanced spectroscopic measurements, microscopic analysis, data interpretation, and dissemination of findings through publications and presentations. Their contributions advanced the project goals and demonstrated significant personal and professional growth. The training prepared graduates for diverse and impactful career trajectories, including pursuing Ph.D. programs at research universities (3), serving the U.S. Department of Defense (2), completing dual degrees at North Carolina State University (2), becoming a NASA mentor (1), securing positions as engineering technicians in industry (2), working as a science teacher at a local school (1), and serving as a lab technician at a university (1). This project fostered a pipeline of highly skilled and diverse STEM professionals.

The project made broader impacts on science, technology, and STEM education. The development of radiation detection technologies introduced applications in diverse areas, such as scientific experimentation, safety inspections, and product testing. Optical sensing with conjugated polymers and small molecules provided a streamlined approach to chemical detection. At the same time, immunosensors based on oxide nanofibers showed promise for applications in biology, food science, and environmental monitoring. These advancements can improve hazard detection, enable early disease diagnostics, and monitor environmental conditions. The versatility of these nanosensor technologies indicates their potential to address challenges critical to societal needs.

Integrating this research into educational initiatives further amplified its impact by enhancing the quality of STEM education at FSU. Students from multiple STEM disciplines benefited from evidence-based teaching practices to improve engagement and foster collaboration in advanced research. These efforts increased student enrollment, retention, and graduation rates, better preparing students for STEM career development. This project produced a highly motivated and diverse cohort of materials science professionals and STEM leaders equipped to address multidisciplinary challenges. By fostering an innovative and inclusive STEM workforce, the project advanced scientific discoveries and technological development while creating a lasting, positive impact on FSU’s research capabilities.


Last Modified: 12/19/2024
Modified by: Zhiping Luo
